title: Pluralistic: The long lineage of private equity’s looting (02 June 2023) – Pluralistic: Daily links from Cory Doctorow

last_post.content:
The Sears case cuts to bone

With its massive catalog, >100y experience w production/inventory/fulfillment & millions of devoted customers, Sears was ideally positioned to move online as THE dominant online retailer

Instead, investors [edited to add: /management] gutted the golden goose

And that’s just one example in @pluralistic’s rundown of the long history of heists like this being pulled by private equity

https://pluralistic.net/2023/06/02/plunderers/#

Yes. Very good take on the AI frenzy.
“arguments about which regulation we should create to stop the plausible sentence machine from becoming sentient and reducing us all to grey goo are a lot more fun — and profitable — than arguments about making it easier for workers to unionize, or banning companies from practicing wage discrimination, or using anticompetitive practices to maintain monopolies.”
https://doctorow.medium.com/ayyyyyy-eyeeeee-4ac92fa2eed

Speaking of copying Mastodon's implementation, I have a funny story.

Have you heard of https://socialhub.activitypub.rocks ? It's a hub for AP devs, I started it in 2019 using a domain I recycled from my first ActivityPub project attempt.

Before I created @pixelfed, I made a GNU/social successor from scratch, it was almost ready until I realized I made a huge mistake, I didn't account for remote profiles.

I almost gave up, and later started Pixelfed by copying Mastodon's database schema

Never give up 😉

title: Sci-fi writer Ted Chiang: ‘The machines we have now are not conscious’

last_post.content:
Ted Chiang:

“There was an exchange on Twitter a while back where someone said, ‘What is artificial intelligence?’ And someone else said, ‘A poor choice of words in 1954’,” he says. “And, you know, they’re right. I think that if we had chosen a different phrase for it, back in the ’50s, we might have avoided a lot of the confusion that we’re having now.

So if he had to invent a term, what would it be? His answer is instant: applied statistics.”

title: How might adding search change Mastodon?

last_post.content:
Good question about online conversations: "Is the discourse predominantly friendly or hostile? What kinds of community norms govern interactions?"
https://write.as/ulrikehahn/how-might-adding-search-change-mastodon

Spread of emotions on a social networks require certain level of visibility to reactions of other people. But if a system is designed to limit visibility, contagion effect is potentially smaller.

But how do people see the reactions if they only see the text output, not the other expressions of emotional reactions?

title: The Identity Theory of Autism: How Autistic Identity Is Experienced Differently

last_post.content:
'I asked people one question: Who are you?

Almost unilaterally, non-autistic people began describing themselves in terms of their relationships to others– if they were a parent, a spouse, what their career was, where they lived, what their religion is, and what their roles were related to others (sister to a Senator, military brat, pastor’s wife, soccer mom, etc.).

And, almost unilaterally, #Autistic people described themselves as what they loved to do, what their values were, and what they had experienced. Many even said this, having intuited the basis of the theory. Among the answers were, “I am a verb,” or “I am what I love,” or “Who I am is what I do.” Autistics would answer, “Lover of Justice,” or “Dreamer,” or “One who values autonomy.” Some would describe themselves as a “lover of” or “obsessed with” an intense passion, like trains, lichen and fungi, or theoretical physics and black holes.'

@actuallyautistic

#Autism #Neurodivergence #Identity

https://neuroclastic.com/the-identity-theory-of-autism-how-autistic-identity-is-experienced-differently/

While doing research I'm working often with maps. There is a lot of interesting geographic data around but I have difficulty to handle QGIS and related file type (geojson, gpkg, shp, etc.), and it's hard to use for teaching.

Some time ago, I discovered @felt and now I've finally lifted these difficulties.

For instance, today I was looking at a paper on Global mining footprint and I was able to use their data in a matter of minutes, here is the result : https://felt.com/map/Global-mining-footprint-FhngephpTdWu9ChFO4rwIQA?lat=17.622631&lon=-9&zoom=3

Anonymizing peer review makes the process more just https://doi.org/10.1038/d41586-023-01772-w

Disappointing (but perhaps not surprising) to see this evidence of prestige bias.

However, while one may argue that anonymization makes peer review more just, I'd argue it also inhibits normal ways of communicating between researchers. I see this as major drawback!

I think peer review can also be made more just by moving away from accept/reject decisions, and this has the benefit that it doesn't require anonymization.

A billboard in Linz, Austria, fitted with an atmospheric CO2 reading taken from @gordo and my project PerMillion (https://permillion.live). The billboard features as part of the Linz FMR festival (https://www.linzfmr.at/), opening June 6, and will be changed each day in sync with readings from our site.

This whole thread is great, but I think we also need to think hard about what to do when corporations do get governmental (or even supergovernmental) power. The fact that this has happened is, in my opinion, a big problem. Corporations like Google and Facebook do have government sized control over speech, far less accountability, and their sheer scale distorts the compensating social processes so far beyond what those systems would ordinarily handle.

They also have hegemonic power.

I am currently enjoying this article* on Roman roads. I think the real pullquote from the opening is this point:

"Roman roads, in one sense, weren’t revolutionary. They were an old idea, but an old idea employed on a much larger scale and as is often the case differences in scale and implementation can become differences in kind."

title: Why we need to respect Earth’s last great wilderness – the ocean

last_post.content:
“Instead of seeing the ocean as a “solution” for climate change, we need to see it as a test of a new attitude to our planet, one that doesn’t treat it as a combination of universal rubbish bin and exploitable resource. Ask not what the ocean can do for you, but what you can do for the ocean.”

My piece in the Observer today, about the growing attitude that we can just “use” the ocean as if it’s not doing anything useful to start with: https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/jun/04/why-we-need-to-respect-earths-last-great-wilderness-the-ocean

title: Computer Shopper January 1987 : Free Download, Borrow, and Streaming : Internet Archive

last_post.content:
Another issue of Computer Shopper is now scanned in: January 1987. I would say I "get it", now: the process loses none of the data, and I'm keeping the pages rather straight through the scanner. This is VERY hard work.

The pages will eventually have cropped/color-leveled versions up, but for now, I made the RAW versions browsable so you can get the value now:

https://archive.org/details/computer-shopper-january-1987
